attributes.action: Remove 5% VAT rate on gas and electric bills
attributes.additional_details:
Everything goes up in price every year to meet inflation and it doesn’t make any difference when we earn more money in our wages it never will until we see taxes being reduced not increases of an hourly rate (£ph) we know of other taxes they include
Council tax, income tax, national insurance, inheritance tax, stamp duty, vehicle excise duty (road tax), capital gains tax, corporate tax, consumption tax, fuel tax, etc. It’s clear to see that there are other ways of getting money from the public.
attributes.background: Surely the general population would agree that one of the answers to the energy/living costs rising should be to stop charging a 5% VAT rate on our energy bills. Gas and Electricity are a necessity in the modern world. We would struggle to live without them especially the vulnerable.

other_parliamentary_business.body:
The MPs on the House of Commons Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy Committee have been investigating energy pricing and the energy market, including Government support to help people with their energy bills.
Report on energy pricing and the energy market
In July the Committee published a report on energy pricing and the energy market. In their report, MPs called on the Government to help the most exposed households by updating its energy bills support. They also called on the Government to consider a social tariff for the most vulnerable customers.
Read the Committee's report on energy pricing and the energy market (https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm5803/cmselect/cmbeis/236/report.html)
Read a press release about the report (https://committees.parliament.uk/committee/365/business-energy-and-industrial-strategy-committee/news/172350/government-must-update-energy-bills-support-as-crisis-outpaces-help-say-mps/)
Evidence session on the cost of living crisis
Last month the Committee questioned business representatives, unions and consumer groups about climbing energy bills, inflation, interest rates, food and material costs, the impact these trends are having, and how they expect the crisis to develop.
Find out more about the Committee's evidence session on the cost of living crisis (https://committees.parliament.uk/committee/365/business-energy-and-industrial-strategy-committee/news/172926/costofliving-crisis-industry-leaders-and-unions-give-evidence-on-how-business-and-workers-are-reacting/)
Read a transcript of the evidence session (https://committees.parliament.uk/event/14489/formal-meeting-oral-evidence-session/)
Select Committee podcast
The Chair of the Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy Committee, Darren Jones MP, is hosting the current series of the Committee Corridor podcast. This is a fortnightly podcast that brings together Members of Parliament from the different select committees in the House of Commons to interview experts and discuss the most pressing political, social and economic matters facing the UK today.
The current series is focusing on the cost of living, and in the first episode Darren spoke to the Chief Executive of the Resolution Foundation, and the MPs who Chair the Women and Equalities and Work and Pensions Committee.
Find out more about the Committee Corridor podcast, including how to subscribe (https://www.parliament.uk/business/commons/committee-corridor-podcast/?utm_source=petcom&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=committee-corridor-s2)
What is the Home Affairs Committee?
The Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy Committee is a cross-party group of backbench MPs that looks into the work of the Home Office and its associated public bodies.
Find out more about the Committee (https://committees.parliament.uk/committee/365/business-energy-and-industrial-strategy-committee/)
Follow the Committee on Twitter (https://twitter.com/commonsbeis) for updates on its work.
The Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy Committee is a select committee. Find out how select committees work. (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=o_2RDuDs44c)
Get involved in the work of the UK Parliament
Sign up to the Your UK Parliament newsletter (https://parliament.us16.list-manage.com/subscribe?u=3ad7e4c57a864f07e4db008c4&id=26d0645ea9) for the latest information on how to get involved and make a difference.
